> I shall try to explain more clearly:
> 
> if(some condition is true) {
> 	do some work;
> 	return result1;
> }
> else {
> 	do some other work;
> 	return result2;
> }
> 
> Here are two execution paths within a procedure. Both
> result1 and result2 might be identical in value some
> of the time, for a many to one function.

If you only assert the return value you know which path you took (if 
return values are different) but not necessarely if you did the job 
right.  You should also assert the results of the "do some work" and "do 
some other work" (side-effects, e.g. some variables are updated).

If no variable is updated and it's only the computation of the return 
value that is executed, you have to choose the input of your tests so 
that these return values are different.

-Vladimir
